body: I believe the intent of this issue was to discuss how we want to support Node.js versions going forward, and not necessarily just about the Node 8.10 issues we are currently dealing with?

rename.from: Consider adding support for earlier Node versions on the 6.x and 8.x release lines
rename.to: Decide how to manage support for minor versions of Node

body: It seems like this one fell through the cracks but is important to address.

I see this issue was assigned to me but I'm not sure of the best way to proceed. My thoughts on the question are the same as they were in the TSC meeting:

> My opinion on this is that I think there are advantages to only supporting newer versions (and I wouldn't want to drop it to 6.0.0/8.0.0), although I don't feel strongly about drawing the lines exactly where they are now. However, I would have concerns about the precedent of adding support for a Node version just because a particular user is still on that version -- it seems like there could be a slippery slope.

Yeah, I think there's a general agreement that adding back support for
older Node versions once it's been decided to drop them is not a good idea.

It seems like the goal here is really to figure out how we decide to stop
supporting point versions of Node.js going forward. I guess, more
specifically, should that be a breaking change or not? I can see arguments
both ways. It should be a breaking change because doing a minor upgrade of
ESLint shouldn't force you to upgrade Node.js; it should not be a breaking
change because we want to stay current with LTS, both for our ability to
make sure of new features and as a carrot to encourage users to upgrade
Node.js to the latest LTS.

I think dropping support for point versions of Node is a breaking change for the reason you mentioned (doing a minor upgrade of ESLint shouldn't force you to upgrade Node.js). While it would be nice to be able to use new features as they come out, that doesn't free us from our compatibility requirements. As a result, I think we need to commit to a set of Node version requirements for any major release line of ESLint (e.g. ESLint v5.x), and we can't tighten those requirements during that release line, although we can loosen those requirements if we want to.

In my view, the goal of this discussion should be to figure out how we decide what requirements to commit to at the start of a major release, and under what conditions (if any) we would loosen those requirements.

Some options include:

1. Picking the current Node version(s) at the time of a major release, and supporting everything at or above it (this is roughly what we did for ESLint 5 by supporting Node `^6.14.0`).
1. Picking a Node version based on specific features that we want to use in ESLint (e.g. next major release, we could decide to only support Node `>=8.9.0` to ensure we can use [the `paths` option in `require.resolve`](https://nodejs.org/api/modules.html#modules_require_resolve_request_options)).
1. Picking the first Node version in a major release line (this is what we did for previous ESLint versions, e.g. ESLint 3 supported Node `>=4.0.0`).
1. Start out with any of the above, and sometimes add support for earlier versions in the middle of a release line based on user demand.

Personally, I think options 1 or 2 are better than options 3 and 4. Based on user feedback, it seems like option 2 might be better than option 1 because it would be less arbitrary.

I can get on board with 2.

Just to be sure I'm understanding, it seems like the difference between 1
and 2 is that 1 would always pick the *latest* Node.js version when the
major ESLint release is done while 2 would always pick the *minimum*
Node.js version required for ESLint to use whatever features we need?

That's correct. It's worth noting that "whatever features we need" would not necessarily be certain in advance (we would have to make a decision by speculating about what features we're likely to want to use over the next major release cycle). As a result, I think we would end up with similar, but slightly looser, requirements than we would with 1.

For example, I imagine the decision could look like this: "Node 8.10 is the current version, but Node 8.10 didn't introduce any features we would realistically use. Node 8.9 did introduce a feature we might want to use, so we'll draw the line at `>= 8.9` rather than `>= 8.10`."

Gotcha. That sounds like a good approach to me.

**TSC Summary:** This proposal is that we decide which versions of Node to support by choosing the lowest point release of first version of Node supporting the features ESLint wants to use. The end result is that we will need to do a bit of research to determine which features we'll want to use whenever a major release happens. (We should also document this policy so we can refer back to it easily.)

**TSC Question:** Shall we accept this proposal?

This proposal was accepted in [yesterday's TSC meeting](https://github.com/eslint/tsc-meetings/blob/137fbe2be55499cd75f28a008900803078d22dfd/notes/2019/2019-03-14.md#decide-how-to-manage-support-for-minor-versions-of-node). The next step is to document the policy, then we can close this issue.
